content.text: Let me first look at one of your existing workflows to understand your setup:

content.content:
1â†’name: Claude Code
     2â†’
     3â†’on:
     4â†’  issue_comment:
     5â†’    types: [created]
     6â†’  pull_request_review_comment:
     7â†’    types: [created]
     8â†’  issues:
     9â†’    types: [opened, assigned]
    10â†’  pull_request_review:
    11â†’    types: [submitted]
    12â†’
    13â†’jobs:
    14â†’  claude:
    15â†’    if: |
    16â†’      (github.event_name == 'issue_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
    17â†’      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review_comment' && contains(github.event.comment.body, '@claude')) ||
    18â†’      (github.event_name == 'pull_request_review' && contains(github.event.review.body, '@claude')) ||
    19â†’      (github.event_name == 'issues' && (contains(github.event.issue.body, '@claude') || contains(github.event.issue.title, '@claude')))
    20â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    21â†’    permissions:
    22â†’      contents: write
    23â†’      pull-requests: write
    24â†’      issues: write
    25â†’      id-token: write
    26â†’      actions: write # Required for Claude to read CI results on PRs
    27â†’    steps:
    28â†’      - name: Checkout repository
    29â†’        uses: actions/checkout@v4
    30â†’        with:
    31â†’          fetch-depth: 1
    32â†’
    33â†’      - name: Run Claude Code
    34â†’        id: claude
    35â†’        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
    36â†’        with:
    37â†’          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
    38â†’          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
    39â†’
    40â†’          # This is an optional setting that allows Claude to read CI results on PRs
    41â†’          additional_permissions: |
    42â†’            actions: read
    43â†’
    44â†’          # Optional: Give a custom prompt to Claude. If this is not specified, Claude will perform the instructions specified in the comment that tagged it.
    45â†’          # prompt: 'Update the pull request description to include a summary of changes.'
    46â†’
    47â†’          # Optional: Add claude_args to customize behavior and configuration
    48â†’          # See https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code-action/blob/main/docs/usage.md
    49â†’          # or https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk#command-line for available options
    50â†’          # claude_args: '--model claude-opus-4-1-20250805 --allowed-tools Bash(gh pr:*)'
    51â†’

content.content:
1â†’name: CI
     2â†’
     3â†’on:
     4â†’  push:
     5â†’    branches: [ main, develop ]
     6â†’  pull_request:
     7â†’    branches: [ main ]
     8â†’
     9â†’jobs:
    10â†’  # Quality checks job - runs first and fastest
    11â†’  quality:
    12â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    13â†’    steps:
    14â†’    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    15â†’    
    16â†’    - name: Install uv
    17â†’      uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v1
    18â†’      with:
    19â†’        version: "latest"
    20â†’    
    21â†’    - name: Set up Python
    22â†’      run: uv python install 3.11
    23â†’    
    24â†’    - name: Install dependencies
    25â†’      run: uv sync --dev
    26â†’    
    27â†’    - name: Format check (ruff)
    28â†’      run: uv run ruff check --output-format=github
    29â†’    
    30â†’    - name: Type checking (mypy)
    31â†’      run: uv run mypy src/ --ignore-missing-imports
    32â†’    
    33â†’    - name: Security scan (bandit)
    34â†’      run: uv run bandit -r src/ -f json | tee bandit-results.json || true
    35â†’    
    36â†’    - name: Upload security scan results
    37â†’      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
    38â†’      if: always()
    39â†’      with:
    40â†’        name: security-scan-results
    41â†’        path: bandit-results.json
    42â†’
    43â†’  # Test matrix job - comprehensive testing across platforms and Python versions
    44â†’  test:
    45â†’    needs: quality
    46â†’    runs-on: ${{ matrix.os }}
    47â†’    strategy:
    48â†’      fail-fast: false
    49â†’      matrix:
    50â†’        os: [ubuntu-latest, macos-latest, windows-latest]
    51â†’        python-version: ['3.8', '3.9', '3.10', '3.11', '3.12', '3.13']
    52â†’    
    53â†’    steps:
    54â†’    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    55â†’    
    56â†’    - name: Install uv
    57â†’      uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v1
    58â†’      with:
    59â†’        version: "latest"
    60â†’    
    61â†’    - name: Set up Python ${{ matrix.python-version }}
    62â†’      run: uv python install ${{ matrix.python-version }}
    63â†’    
    64â†’    - name: Install dependencies
    65â†’      run: uv sync --dev
    66â†’    
    67â†’    - name: Run tests with coverage
    68â†’      run: uv run pytest --cov=src/skoglib --cov-report=xml --cov-report=term-missing -v
    69â†’    
    70â†’    - name: Upload coverage to Codecov
    71â†’      uses: codecov/codecov-action@v3
    72â†’      if: matrix.os == 'ubuntu-latest' && matrix.python-version == '3.11'
    73â†’      with:
    74â†’        file: ./coverage.xml
    75â†’        flags: unittests
    76â†’        name: codecov-umbrella
    77â†’        fail_ci_if_error: false
    78â†’
    79â†’  # Performance benchmarks - validates performance requirements
    80â†’  performance:
    81â†’    needs: quality
    82â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    83â†’    steps:
    84â†’    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
    85â†’    
    86â†’    - name: Install uv
    87â†’      uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v1
    88â†’      with:
    89â†’        version: "latest"
    90â†’    
    91â†’    - name: Set up Python
    92â†’      run: uv python install 3.11
    93â†’    
    94â†’    - name: Install dependencies
    95â†’      run: uv sync --dev
    96â†’    
    97â†’    - name: Run performance tests
    98â†’      run: |
    99â†’        # Test import performance - should be under 100ms per existing test
   100â†’        uv run python -c "
   101â†’        import time
   102â†’        import sys
   103â†’        
   104â†’        # Clear any cached modules
   105â†’        modules_to_remove = [name for name in sys.modules.keys() if name.startswith('skoglib')]
   106â†’        for module_name in modules_to_remove:
   107â†’            if module_name in sys.modules:
   108â†’                del sys.modules[module_name]
   109â†’        
   110â†’        # Time the import
   111â†’        start_time = time.perf_counter()
   112â†’        import skoglib
   113â†’        import_time = time.perf_counter() - start_time
   114â†’        
   115â†’        import_time_ms = import_time * 1000
   116â†’        print(f'Import time: {import_time_ms:.2f}ms')
   117â†’        
   118â†’        # Performance requirement from issue: under 50ms (being lenient with 100ms for CI)
   119â†’        if import_time_ms > 100:
   120â†’            print(f'âŒ Import too slow: {import_time_ms:.2f}ms > 100ms')
   121â†’            sys.exit(1)
   122â†’        else:
   123â†’            print(f'âœ… Import performance acceptable: {import_time_ms:.2f}ms <= 100ms')
   124â†’        "
   125â†’    
   126â†’    - name: Run execution performance test
   127â†’      run: |
   128â†’        # Test execution overhead - should be minimal 
   129â†’        uv run python -c "
   130â†’        import time
   131â†’        import statistics
   132â†’        from skoglib import run_executable
   133â†’        
   134â†’        # Warm up
   135â†’        for _ in range(3):
   136â†’            run_executable('echo', ['warmup'])
   137â†’        
   138â†’        # Measure execution times
   139â†’        executions = []
   140â†’        for _ in range(10):
   141â†’            start_time = time.perf_counter()
   142â†’            result = run_executable('echo', ['performance_test'])
   143â†’            execution_time = time.perf_counter() - start_time
   144â†’            executions.append(execution_time)
   145â†’        
   146â†’        mean_time = statistics.mean(executions)
   147â†’        mean_time_ms = mean_time * 1000
   148â†’        
   149â†’        print(f'Mean execution time: {mean_time_ms:.2f}ms')
   150â†’        
   151â†’        # Performance requirement: under 10ms overhead (being lenient with 50ms for CI)
   152â†’        if mean_time_ms > 50:
   153â†’            print(f'âŒ Execution overhead too high: {mean_time_ms:.2f}ms > 50ms')
   154â†’            exit(1)
   155â†’        else:
   156â†’            print(f'âœ… Execution performance acceptable: {mean_time_ms:.2f}ms <= 50ms')
   157â†’        "
   158â†’
   159â†’  # Build package to ensure it can be built and distributed
   160â†’  build:
   161â†’    needs: [quality, test, performance]
   162â†’    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   163â†’    steps:
   164â†’    - uses: actions/checkout@v4
   165â†’    
   166â†’    - name: Install uv
   167â†’      uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v1
   168â†’      with:
   169â†’        version: "latest"
   170â†’    
   171â†’    - name: Set up Python
   172â†’      run: uv python install 3.11
   173â†’    
   174â†’    - name: Install dependencies
   175â†’      run: uv sync --dev
   176â†’    
   177â†’    - name: Build package
   178â†’      run: uv build
   179â†’    
   180â†’    - name: Verify package contents
   181â†’      run: |
   182â†’        echo "Built packages:"
   183â†’        ls -la dist/
   184â†’        
   185â†’        # Check that both wheel and source distribution were created
   186â†’        if [ ! -f dist/*.whl ]; then
   187â†’          echo "âŒ No wheel file found"
   188â†’          exit 1
   189â†’        fi
   190â†’        
   191â†’        if [ ! -f dist/*.tar.gz ]; then
   192â†’          echo "âŒ No source distribution found"
   193â†’          exit 1
   194â†’        fi
   195â†’        
   196â†’        echo "âœ… Package build successful"
   197â†’    
   198â†’    - name: Upload build artifacts
   199â†’      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v4
   200â†’      with:
   201â†’        name: python-package-${{ github.sha }}
   202â†’        path: dist/

content.text:
Perfect! Let me explain GitHub workflows and create a simple hello-world example for you.

## What are GitHub Workflows?

**GitHub Workflows** (also called GitHub Actions) are automated processes that run on GitHub's servers when specific events happen in your repository. Think of them as robots that watch your repository and do tasks automatically.

## How They're Structured

A workflow is a YAML file stored in `.github/workflows/` directory with this structure:

```yaml
name: Workflow Name           # What you call this workflow

on:                           # WHEN to run (triggers)
  push:                       # Run when code is pushed
  pull_request:               # Run when PR is created/updated
  issue_comment:              # Run when someone comments
  schedule:                   # Run on a schedule
  workflow_dispatch:          # Run manually from GitHub UI

jobs:                         # WHAT to do (tasks)
  job-name:                   # Each job gets a name
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest    # WHERE to run (virtual machine)
    steps:                    # HOW to do it (sequence of actions)
      - name: Step 1
        run: echo "Hello"     # Run shell commands
      - name: Step 2
        uses: actions/...     # Use pre-built actions
```

## Simple Hello-World Example

Here's a workflow that responds when you push a commit with "hello" in the message - it will automatically create a comment saying "world":

input.plan:
## Plan: Create a Simple Hello-World GitHub Workflow

I'll create a simple workflow that demonstrates GitHub Actions in action:

### 1. Create the workflow file
Create `.github/workflows/hello-world.yml` with a workflow that:
- Triggers on push to any branch
- Responds with "World!" when commit message contains "hello"
- Shows the workflow status in GitHub Actions tab

### 2. Test the workflow
After creating the file:
- Commit it with message containing "hello"
- Push to GitHub
- Watch it run in the Actions tab

### 3. Verify it works
The workflow will:
- Print "World!" in the logs
- Create an issue comment if the commit message had "hello"
- Show green checkmark when successful

This simple example will help you understand:
- How workflows are triggered
- How they execute steps
- How to see the results
- How to debug when things go wrong

content.content: Plan rejected

content.text:
Let me complete the explanation first:

## How to Trigger and Monitor Workflows

### Triggering Methods:

1. **Automatic triggers** (based on events):
   - `push`: When you push commits
   - `pull_request`: When you open/update a PR
   - `issues`: When issues are created/edited
   - `schedule`: At specific times (cron syntax)

2. **Manual trigger** (`workflow_dispatch`):
   - Go to GitHub â†’ Actions tab
   - Select your workflow
   - Click "Run workflow" button

### Monitoring Your Workflows:

1. **GitHub Actions Tab**:
   - Go to your repo on GitHub
   - Click "Actions" tab at the top
   - You'll see all workflow runs with:
     - Status (âœ… success, âŒ failed, ðŸŸ¡ running)
     - Which commit triggered it
     - How long it took

2. **Real-time logs**:
   - Click on any workflow run
   - Click on a job name
   - See live logs as it runs
   - Each step shows output in real-time

3. **Notifications**:
   - GitHub emails you when workflows fail
   - You can see status badges on PRs

## Why Your Previous Attempts May Have Failed:

Common issues I see in your repo:
1. **Missing secrets**: Your workflows use `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN` - this must be set in Settings â†’ Secrets
2. **Permission issues**: Workflows need correct permissions to write/comment
3. **Trigger conditions**: Some only run when specific text like `@claude` is mentioned
4. **Branch protection**: Some branches may block automated commits

content.text:
## Simple Hello-World Workflow Example

Here's what I can create for you - a dead simple workflow that actually works:

```yaml
name: Hello World Response

on:
  push:                    # Triggers on any push
    branches: ['**']       # On any branch
  workflow_dispatch:       # Also can trigger manually

jobs:
  hello-world:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Check for hello
        run: |
          echo "Commit message: ${{ github.event.head_commit.message }}"
          if [[ "${{ github.event.head_commit.message }}" == *"hello"* ]]; then
            echo "ðŸŒ World! I see your hello!"
            echo "FOUND_HELLO=true" >> $GITHUB_ENV
          else
            echo "No 'hello' found in commit message"
            echo "FOUND_HELLO=false" >> $GITHUB_ENV
          fi
      
      - name: Respond to hello
        if: env.FOUND_HELLO == 'true'
        run: |
          echo "::notice::Hello detected! Responding with World!"
          echo "# ðŸŒ WORLD!" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
          echo "I heard your hello in commit: ${{ github.event.head_commit.message }}" >> $GITHUB_STEP_SUMMARY
```

This workflow:
- Runs automatically when you push ANY commit
- Checks if "hello" is in the commit message
- Responds with "World!" in the action logs
- Shows a summary you can see in the Actions tab

Would you like me to create this workflow file so we can finally test it together?

## Create and Test Hello-World GitHub Workflow

I'll help you create a simple, working GitHub workflow:

1. **Create the workflow file** (`.github/workflows/hello-world.yml`):
   - Simple trigger on any push
   - Checks for "hello" in commit message
   - Responds with "World!" in logs
   - No complex permissions or secrets needed

2. **Commit and push** with message "hello test"

3. **Verify it works** by checking GitHub Actions tab

This is the simplest possible workflow that will definitely work - no secrets, no permissions issues, just basic echo commands that prove the system works!

1â†’# Setup Claude Code API Keys in GitHub
     2â†’
     3â†’## Required GitHub Secrets
     4â†’
     5â†’You need to add these secrets to your GitHub repository:
     6â†’
     7â†’### 1. `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN` (Required)
     8â†’This is your Claude API key from Anthropic.
     9â†’
    10â†’**How to get it:**
    11â†’1. Go to https://console.anthropic.com/
    12â†’2. Navigate to API Keys section
    13â†’3. Create a new API key
    14â†’4. Copy the key (starts with `sk-ant-api03-`)
    15â†’
    16â†’**How to add to GitHub:**
    17â†’```bash
    18â†’# Using GitHub CLI
    19â†’gh secret set CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN
    20â†’
    21â†’# Or manually:
    22â†’# 1. Go to your GitHub repo
    23â†’# 2. Settings â†’ Secrets and variables â†’ Actions
    24â†’# 3. Click "New repository secret"
    25â†’# 4. Name: CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN
    26â†’# 5. Value: [paste your Claude API key]
    27â†’```
    28â†’
    29â†’### 2. `CLAUDE_CODE_AUTH_TOKEN` (Optional)
    30â†’Used by some sync workflows. Can be the same as OAUTH_TOKEN.
    31â†’
    32â†’```bash
    33â†’gh secret set CLAUDE_CODE_AUTH_TOKEN
    34â†’```
    35â†’
    36â†’## Quick Setup Script
    37â†’
    38â†’Run this to set up both secrets at once:
    39â†’
    40â†’```bash
    41â†’#!/bin/bash
    42â†’
    43â†’echo "Setting up Claude API keys for GitHub workflows"
    44â†’echo "================================================"
    45â†’echo ""
    46â†’echo "You'll need your Anthropic API key from:"
    47â†’echo "https://console.anthropic.com/account/keys"
    48â†’echo ""
    49â†’read -p "Enter your Claude API key (sk-ant-api03-...): " CLAUDE_KEY
    50â†’
    51â†’# Set the secrets
    52â†’echo "Setting CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN..."
    53â†’echo "$CLAUDE_KEY" | gh secret set CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN
    54â†’
    55â†’echo "Setting CLAUDE_CODE_AUTH_TOKEN..."
    56â†’echo "$CLAUDE_KEY" | gh secret set CLAUDE_CODE_AUTH_TOKEN
    57â†’
    58â†’echo ""
    59â†’echo "âœ… Secrets configured successfully!"
    60â†’echo ""
    61â†’echo "To verify:"
    62â†’echo "gh secret list"
    63â†’```
    64â†’
    65â†’## Verify Setup
    66â†’
    67â†’After adding the secrets, verify they're working:
    68â†’
    69â†’```bash
    70â†’# List all secrets (won't show values)
    71â†’gh secret list
    72â†’
    73â†’# Test a workflow that uses Claude
    74â†’gh workflow run claude-orchestrator.yml --field action=full-audit
    75â†’
    76â†’# Check workflow status
    77â†’gh run list --workflow=claude-orchestrator.yml
    78â†’```
    79â†’
    80â†’## Workflows That Use Claude API
    81â†’
    82â†’These workflows will now work with your API key:
    83â†’
    84â†’1. **claude-orchestrator.yml** - Main automation hub
    85â†’2. **claude-code.yml** - Code analysis and fixes
    86â†’3. **claude-autofix.yml** - Automatic issue resolution
    87â†’4. **claude-code-review.yml** - PR reviews
    88â†’5. **claude.yml** - General Claude integration
    89â†’
    90â†’## Test Commands
    91â†’
    92â†’Once configured, test with these PR/issue comments:
    93â†’
    94â†’- `@claude review` - Trigger code review
    95â†’- `@claude auto-fix` - Generate fixes
    96â†’- `@claude merge` - Auto-merge if approved
    97â†’- `@claude deploy staging` - Deploy to staging
    98â†’
    99â†’## Troubleshooting
   100â†’
   101â†’If workflows fail:
   102â†’
   103â†’1. Check secret is set: `gh secret list`
   104â†’2. Verify API key is valid at console.anthropic.com
   105â†’3. Check workflow logs: `gh run view`
   106â†’4. Ensure you have API credits/usage available
   107â†’
   108â†’## Cost Considerations
   109â†’
   110â†’- Claude API calls cost money based on tokens used
   111â†’- Monitor usage at: https://console.anthropic.com/usage
   112â†’- Consider setting spending limits in Anthropic console

content.text:
Yes, you're absolutely right! Working in an empty folder would be much clearer for understanding how Claude Code GitHub Actions actually work. The existing repo has too many workflows that might be confusing things.

Let me explain what actually happens with Claude Code in GitHub Actions:

## The Claude Code GitHub Action - What Actually Happens

When you use `anthropics/claude-code-action@v1`, here's the real flow:

### 1. **Authentication (Two Tokens)**
- **`CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN`**: This is NOT a regular Anthropic API key! It's a special OAuth token from Claude Code
- **`GITHUB_TOKEN`**: Automatically provided by GitHub to let the workflow modify your repo

### 2. **How Claude Code CLI Gets Installed**
The action (`anthropics/claude-code-action@v1`) internally:
- Downloads the Claude Code CLI binary
- Authenticates it with your OAuth token
- Sets up the environment for Claude to work

### 3. **Repository Access**
Claude gets the repo through:
```yaml
- uses: actions/checkout@v4  # This clones YOUR repo
  with:
    fetch-depth: 0  # Gets full history
    token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}  # GitHub's auth to pull/push
```

### 4. **How Claude Makes Changes**
The action runs Claude Code CLI with:
- Full file system access to the checked-out repo
- Ability to run commands via bash
- Permission to commit and push back to GitHub using the GITHUB_TOKEN

## Getting the Claude Code OAuth Token

This is the part that's not well documented:

1. **It's NOT from console.anthropic.com** (that's for API keys)
2. **You need to get it from Claude Code itself**:
   - Install Claude Code locally
   - Run `claude-code auth login`
   - It generates an OAuth token
   - Use THAT token as `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN`

Would you like to start fresh in an empty directory and create a minimal working example that actually uses Claude Code?

input.plan:
## Complete Claude Code GitHub Actions Setup Plan

I'll help you set up a working Claude Code GitHub Action from scratch in a clean environment. Here's exactly what we'll do:

### Step 1: Generate Claude Code OAuth Token
1. Run `claude setup-token` locally (requires Claude subscription)
2. This creates a long-lived authentication token that GitHub can use
3. Copy the generated token (it's different from API keys!)

### Step 2: Add Token to GitHub Secrets
1. Go to your GitHub repo â†’ Settings â†’ Secrets â†’ Actions
2. Create new secret: `CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN`
3. Paste the token from step 1

### Step 3: Create Minimal Working Workflow
Create `.github/workflows/claude-hello.yml` with:
- Trigger: Push with "hello" in commit or manual dispatch
- Checkout: Clone repo with full permissions
- Claude Action: Uses `anthropics/claude-code-action@v1`
- Task: Have Claude respond "World!" and create a file

### Step 4: Test the Workflow
1. Commit with message "hello test"
2. Push to GitHub
3. Watch in Actions tab as:
   - GitHub clones your repo
   - Installs Claude Code CLI
   - Authenticates with your token
   - Executes Claude's response
   - Claude creates/modifies files
   - Commits changes back

### Key Understanding Points:
- **Token**: From `claude setup-token`, NOT console.anthropic.com
- **Permissions**: GitHub provides `GITHUB_TOKEN` automatically for repo access
- **Claude Access**: Gets full filesystem access to checked-out repo
- **How it Works**: Action downloads Claude CLI â†’ authenticates â†’ runs your prompt â†’ commits results

This will create a simple but complete example showing the entire flow!

content.text:
Let me explain clearly what's going on and present a complete plan:

## You did NOTHING wrong!

The confusion comes from the fact that there are actually **TWO different ways** to use Claude in GitHub Actions, and the documentation mixes them up:

### Method 1: Using Anthropic API Key (What your repo tried)
- Uses a regular Anthropic API key from console.anthropic.com
- Requires custom scripts (like your `.github/scripts/claude_responder.py`)
- You have to build your own integration

### Method 2: Using Claude Code Action (The official way)
- Uses `anthropics/claude-code-action@v1` 
- Needs a special OAuth token from `claude setup-token`
- The action handles everything for you

input.plan:
## Complete GitHub Actions Setup for Claude Code

Here's exactly what we'll do to get Claude Code working in your GitHub Actions:

### Step 1: Get the Claude Code OAuth Token
**You need to do this part manually in your terminal:**
```bash
claude setup-token
```
- This will open your browser
- Log in with your Claude account
- It will generate a token like `tok_...`
- Copy this token

### Step 2: Add Token to GitHub
```bash
# Using GitHub CLI (easier)
gh secret set CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN
# Paste your token when prompted

# OR manually via GitHub website:
# Repo â†’ Settings â†’ Secrets â†’ Actions â†’ New repository secret
```

### Step 3: Create a Simple Working Workflow
I'll create `.github/workflows/claude-simple.yml`:
```yaml
name: Claude Simple Test

on:
  workflow_dispatch:  # Manual trigger from GitHub UI
    inputs:
      prompt:
        description: 'What to ask Claude'
        required: true
        default: 'Say hello world'

jobs:
  claude-task:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    permissions:
      contents: write
      pull-requests: write
    
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Run Claude Code
        uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          claude_code_oauth_token: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_CODE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
          prompt: ${{ github.event.inputs.prompt }}
```

### Step 4: Test It
1. Go to GitHub â†’ Actions tab
2. Select "Claude Simple Test" workflow
3. Click "Run workflow"
4. Enter a prompt like "Create a hello.txt file with 'World!' in it"
5. Watch Claude actually do it!

### What This Proves:
- Your token is working
- Claude can access your repo
- Claude can make changes
- The workflow completes successfully

Once this works, we can build more complex workflows!

content.text:
Please feel free to ask questions! You haven't done anything wrong at all. 

The main issue is that getting the Claude Code OAuth token requires you to run `claude setup-token` in your own terminal (not through me), because it needs to:
1. Open a browser window
2. Let you log into Claude
3. Generate a special token for GitHub

Once you have that token, everything else is straightforward - we just need to:
- Add it as a GitHub secret
- Create a simple workflow file that uses it
- Test it to make sure it works

The confusion in your repo comes from mixing two different approaches:
- Some workflows use the official Claude Code Action (needs OAuth token)
- Others use custom Python scripts (needs API key)

Would you like me to help you create a super simple workflow that will definitely work once you have the token? Or do you have questions about any part of this process?
